sect1.title: For MySQL
sect1.para: The following limitations apply to MySQL databases accessed via Libgda: none.

sect1.title: For Oracle
sect1.para:
The following limitations apply to Oracle databases accessed via Libgda:
At the moment tables' fields shema information retreival is very slow, so as a work around, use a dictionary to store the database schema and do incremental updates on modified/created tables.

sect1.title: For PostgreSQL
sect1.para: The following limitations apply to PostgreSQL databases accessed via Libgda:

listitem.para: Postgres uses the "Oid" data type to internally store BLOBs, but this type is also used to store other information within the database. Libgda assumes that any column of type "Oid" represents a blob. If this is not the case, then you must cast it to the correct data type within your SQL query (for example as "SELECT oid::varchar FROM...")

As Libgda tries as much as possible to avoid orphaned BLOBs, it assumes that any BLOB Oid is present in at most one column of a table (and if not present, then the BLOB is orphaned); if a same BLOB is present in more than one column of a table, then expect some problems.
BLOB manipulations can only occur within a transaction, so you should start a transaction before any operation on BLOBs, otherwise Libgda will automatically start one

sect1.title: For SQLite
sect1.para: The following limitations apply to SQLite databases accessed via Libgda: none.
